isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1995) - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - CIRCUIT FUNCTION AND DIAGNOSTICS - ENGINE COOLANT LEVEL SYSTEM (ENGINE PROTECTION)

para.hotlnk: Figure 3.48 Engine Coolant Level System (Engine Protection)

figure.caption: Figure 3.48 Engine Coolant Level System (Engine Protection)

svcsubproc.title: SIGNAL FUNCTION
svcsubproc.para: With the optional engine protection system, the ECM monitors inputs from the Engine Oil Pressure sensor, Engine Coolant Temperature sensor and Low Coolant switch (or module). If any of these sensors detect out of range conditions beyond the warning level, ECM OWL terminal 59 goes LOW (grd) causing the alarm to sound and the oil/water warning light to turn ON. If the engine shutdown feature has been selected, and the out of range conditions go beyond the critical level, the engine will initate the shutdown process.

svcsubproc.title: Low Coolant Level System
svcsubproc.para: The 2500, 2600, 8100 models have a metal surge tank and use low coolant module and low coolant probe. All other models with a plastic composite surge tank utilize a magnetic low coolant switch in the surge tank instead of the module and probe.
2500, 2600, 8100 Models - The low coolant module outputs a 12V signal to ECM terminal when coolant levels are at specified levels and 0V when coolant is below the probe.

Models With Plastic Surge Tank -The low coolant switch is open when coolant is OK and closed when coolant is LOW. When this switch OPEN, 12V is present at ECM terminal 18. When the switch is closed, voltage is pulled to zero at ECM terminal 18.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Oil Pressure Sensor
svcsubproc.para: The Engine Oil Pressure (EOP) sensor sends a linear analog signal to ECM terminal 42. If the ECM detects oil pressure below the warning level the OWL is turned on. If oil pressure goes below the critical level, engine shutdown is initiated. Refer to Engine Oil Pressure (EOP) Sensor diagnostics for additional information and sensor circuit troubleshooting.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Coolant Temperature Sensor
svcsubproc.para: The Engine Coolant Temperature (ECT) sensor sends a 0-5 volt analog signal to ECM terminal 7. If the ECM detects coolant temperature above the warning level the OWL is turned on. If coolant temperature goes above the critical level, engine shutdown is initiated. Refer to Engine Coolant Temperature (ECT) Sensor diagnostics for additional information and sensor circuit troubleshooting.

svcsubproc.title: FAULT DETECTION MANANGEMENT
svcsubproc.para: There are no ECM diagnostics for the Engine Coolant Level system. Flash Code 323 will be active when a low coolant situation is present and the Prolink will indicate COOLANT LOW. After the coolant has been restored to proper levels, Flash code 323 will remain as an inactive code and the ECM will log the engine hours of the occurrence.

para.hotlnk: Figure 3.49 ECL System Diagnostics Models With Metal Surge Tank

figure.caption: Figure 3.49 ECL System Diagnostics Models With Metal Surge Tank

svcsubproc.para: Connector Voltage Checks
Connector (414) with key ON, probe submerged in coolant and coolant module disconnected

entry.para: < than 10.5 v check connections, if 0 volts check for open/short to ground or blown fuse.
< than 10.5 v check connections, if 0 volts check for open/short to ground or blown fuse.
0 volts check for open in probe circuit < less than 5V check connections and check probe for clean condition.
< than 10.5 volts check connections. 0 volts check for open circuit 34B.

svcsubproc.para: Operational Check
ECM Connector (379) with breakout box installed, probe submerged in coolant and key ON

entry.para: < than 10.5 v check connections, if 0 volts check for open/short to grd in circuit 34B.
323 = Indicates low coolant level. If coolant level full with code present, troubleshoot circuit.

svcsubproc.title: MODELS WITH PLASTIC SURGE TANK

para.hotlnk: Figure 3.50 ECL System Diagnostics on Models With Plastic Surge Tank

figure.caption: Figure 3.50 ECL System Diagnostics on Models With Plastic Surge Tank

svcsubproc.para: Harness side of connector (437) - disconnected with key ON

entry.para: < than 10.5 v check connections, if 0 volts check for open/short to ground or blown fuse
< than 10.5 v check connections, if 0 volts check for open in ground path.

svcsubproc.para: Switch side of connector (437) - disconnected with key OFF and coolant at proper level

entry.para: < than 1000 ohms replace the switch (s/b less than 5 ohms with low coolant level)

svcsubproc.para: Connector (379) with breakout box installed and key ON and coolant at proper level with (437)
connected to ECL switch.

entry.para: < than 10.5v check connections, if 0 volts check for open/short to ground or blown fuse or defective resistor.
323 = Indicates low coolant level. If coolant level full with code present, troubleshoot circuit.

svcsubproc.title: EXTENDED DESCRIPTION MODELS WITH METAL SURGE TANK

note.para: Refer to Extended Description for models with plastic surge tanks.

svcsubproc.para: With the optional engine protection system, the ECM monitors inputs from the Engine Oil Pressure sensor, Engine Coolant Temperature sensor and Low Coolant switch (or module). If any of these sensors detect out of range conditions beyond the warning level, ECM OWL terminal 59 goes LOW (grd) causing the alarm to sound and the oil/water warning light to turn ON. If the engine shutdown feature has been selected, and the out of range conditions go beyond the critical level, the engine will initate the shutdown process.

svcsubproc.title: Engine COOLANT LEVEL (ECL) MODULE AND PROBE
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to the circuit diagram Figure 3.51
or the following discussion.

The ECL module (414) receives 12V ignition power from 15A fuse F2 (G1 fuse w/FBC) at terminals A and C. ECL Module, Terminal B is connected (circuit 34B) through connector (379) to ECM terminal 18 (CLS).

ECL module (414) is grounded from terminal D through the Coolant Level Probe located in the surge tank. The ground path (very low current flow in the circuit) from ECL module terminal D goes through the probe and the coolant (using coolant as a conductor) on circuit 34-G to the starter ground. When the coolant level is above the probe, ECL module terminal B will be HIGH (12V) causing ECM connector (379) CLS terminal 18 to be HIGH. This in turn causes ECM connector (379) OWL terminal 59 to be HIGH and Oil/Water Warning Light is OFF.

With coolant level below the probe for more than 7 consecutive seconds (7 second delay prevents intermittent splashing signals), the ground path through the probe from ECL Module terminal D will be open. This causes the ECL module terminal B to go LOW (0 volts). With ECL terminal B at 0 volts, ECM terminal 18 is at 0 volts causing the ECM to turn on the Engine Warning Light and Alarm.

svcsubproc.title: DIAGNOSTIC CODES
svcsubproc.para: The ECM does not check the ECL circuits. Flash Code 323 is set indicating that a "low coolant" condition was detected.

svcsubproc.title: Flash Code 323

para.title: ECM: Engine Coolant Below Warning/Critical Level

svcsubproc.para: Flash Code 323 will be active when a low coolant situation is present and the Prolink will indicate COOLANT LOW. After the coolant has been restored to proper levels, Flash code 323 will remain as an inactive code and the ECM will log the engine hours of the occurrence.

svcsubproc.title: TROUBLESHOOTING
svcsubproc.para: Use the Prolink 9000 to monitor the ECL system operation. Prolink will indicate that the coolant level is FULL or LOW.

step1.para: Before troubleshooting, make sure that the batteries are fully charged! Check battery connections and grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage. Voltage tests will give mis-leading readings if batteries are not fully charged.

Before troubleshooting a particular circuit, inspect connectors for pushed back, loose or damaged (spread or bent) terminals, or wires with cut strands, etc. The wires and connections must be free of damage or corrosion. When some connectors corrode, a light white residue will be present that must be removed.
Before troubleshooting, inspect suspect circuit grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage.

figure.caption: Figure 3.51 Circuit Diagram with 2500, 2600, or 8100 Models with Metal Surge Tank

svcsubproc.title: ENGINE COOLANT LEVEL MODULE AND PROBE TEST (MODELS WITH METAL SURGE TANK.)
svcsubproc.para: Perform Testing For False Low Coolant Signal if Prolink indicates COOLANT LOW when coolant level is above the probe.

svcsubproc.title: EXTENDED DESCRIPTION MODELS WITH PLASTIC SURGE TANKS
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to circuit diagram Figure 3.53
for the following discussion.

With the optional engine protection system, the ECM monitors inputs from the Engine Oil Pressure sensor, Engine Coolant Temperature sensor and Low Coolant switch (or module). If any of these sensors detect out of range conditions beyond the warning level, ECM OWL terminal 59 goes LOW (grd) causing the alarm to sound and the oil/water warning light to turn ON. If the engine shutdown feature has been selected, and the out of range conditions go beyond the critical level, the engine will initate the shutdown process.

svcsubproc.title: ENGINE COOLANT LEVEL SWITCH
svcsubproc.para: Ignition voltage is applied through a 1000 ohm resistor to the Engine Low Coolant (ECL) switch (437) and to ECM connector (379) at terminal 18. ECL switch (437) is open with coolant at proper levels and closed when the coolant level is below required levels.
With the ECL switch open voltage at ECM terminal 18 is HIGH and with coolant low (switch closed) voltage at ECM terminal 18 is LOW.

With ECM terminal 18 HIGH, ECM terminal 59 is also high and the Oil/Water Warning system is not activated. With ECM terminal 18 LOW, terminal 59 is LOW and the warning system is activated turning on the Oil/Water Warning light and initiating the engine shutdown process (if shutdown is enabled).

svcsubproc.title: DIAGNOSTIC CODES
svcsubproc.para: The ECM does not check the ECL circuits. Flash Code 323 is set indicating that a "low coolant" condition was detected.

svcsubproc.title: Flash Code 323

para.title: ECM: Engine Coolant Below Warning/Critical Level

svcsubproc.para: Flash Code 323 will be active when a low coolant situation is present and the Prolink will indicate COOLANT LOW. After the coolant has been restored to proper levels, Flash code 323 will remain as an inactive code and the ECM will log the engine hours of the occurrence.

svcsubproc.title: TROUBLESHOOTING
svcsubproc.para: Use the Prolink 9000 to monitor the ECL system operation. Prolink will indicate that the coolant level is FULL or LOW.

step1.para: Before troubleshooting, make sure that the batteries are fully charged! Check battery connections and grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage. Voltage tests will give mis-leading readings if batteries are not fully charged.

Before troubleshooting a particular circuit, inspect connectors for pushed back, loose or damaged (spread or bent) terminals, or wires with cut strands, etc. The wires and connections must be free of damage or corrosion. When some connectors corrode, a light white residue will be present that must be removed.
Before troubleshooting, inspect suspect circuit grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage.
